pull.title: small init.cpp changes (strings / Winsock init)
pull.body:
- add a check that requested Winsock version is available
- update some strings
- remove -gen=0 from help-message as this is default

events.body: ACK if pulltester is happy with this.

Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/22b0907a7ad099907cff6e0086c5b098a4fc27e2 for binaries and test log.
This test script verifies pulls every time they are updated. It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.  If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/current/
Contact BlueMatt on freenode if something looks broken.
On the winsock version check, this isn't creating a gratuitous incompatibility with a "future" version is it?

Winsock 2.2 was released in 1996, and doesn't seem to have changed much. I doubt the version will change much still. The API specifies that if you request a lower version than the latest one supported, you still get the one you requested. So it shouldn't matter much, but it should be safe.

ACK
I don't see this check actually failing in the life of the universe, but
better to have too many sanity checks than too few.

Just updated the commit-msg:

`remove -par=0 from help-message as this is default`
replaced with
`remove -genr=0 from help-message as this is default`

Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/6f7b79d07e4a3772716a1a0d44607ab0244923ed for binaries and test log.
This test script verifies pulls every time they are updated. It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.  If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/current/
Contact BlueMatt on freenode if something looks broken.
@sipa As pulltester is happy, can you merge it, so I can create another translations update :).

events.message:
small init.cpp changes (strings / Winsock init)

- add a check that requested Winsock version is available
- update some strings
- remove -gen=0 from help-message as this is default

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -358,7 +357,7 @@ bool static Bind(const CService &addr, unsigned int flags) {
         "  -txindex               " + _("Maintain a full transaction index (default: 0)") + "\n" +
         "  -loadblock=<file>      " + _("Imports blocks from external blk000??.dat file") + "\n" +
         "  -reindex               " + _("Rebuild block chain index from current blk000??.dat files") + "\n" +
-        "  -par=N                 " + _("Set the number of script verification threads (up to 16, 0=auto, negative=leave N CPUs free, default: 0)") + "\n" +
+        "  -par=<n>               " + _("Set the number of script verification threads (up to 16, 0 = auto, negative = leave <n> CPUs free, default: 0)") + "\n" +
comments.body: Technically, that should be "leave -n CPUs free"...

+        "  -par=<n>               " + _("Set the number of script verification threads (up to 16, 0 = auto, negative = leave <n> CPUs free, default: 0)") + "\n" +
comments.body: If n is negative, it means that we'll leave -n cores free, not n free (leaving a negative number free is kinda meaningless).

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -358,7 +357,7 @@ bool static Bind(const CService &addr, unsigned int flags) {
         "  -txindex               " + _("Maintain a full transaction index (default: 0)") + "\n" +
         "  -loadblock=<file>      " + _("Imports blocks from external blk000??.dat file") + "\n" +
         "  -reindex               " + _("Rebuild block chain index from current blk000??.dat files") + "\n" +
-        "  -par=N                 " + _("Set the number of script verification threads (up to 16, 0=auto, negative=leave N CPUs free, default: 0)") + "\n" +
+        "  -par=<n>               " + _("Set the number of script verification threads (up to 16, 0 = auto, negative = leave <n> CPUs free, default: 0)") + "\n" +
comments.body:
I don't get it (string wise)... do you consider `-n` in that case as "minus n" or "dash n"?
Anyway ^^, is `<0 = leave <-n> CPUs free` okay then, so I can update?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -358,7 +357,7 @@ bool static Bind(const CService &addr, unsigned int flags) {
         "  -txindex               " + _("Maintain a full transaction index (default: 0)") + "\n" +
         "  -loadblock=<file>      " + _("Imports blocks from external blk000??.dat file") + "\n" +
         "  -reindex               " + _("Rebuild block chain index from current blk000??.dat files") + "\n" +
-        "  -par=N                 " + _("Set the number of script verification threads (up to 16, 0=auto, negative=leave N CPUs free, default: 0)") + "\n" +
+        "  -par=<n>               " + _("Set the number of script verification threads (up to 16, 0 = auto, negative = leave <n> CPUs free, default: 0)") + "\n" +
comments.body:
Minus n. If n is negative, -n is positive, and -n is how many cores we'll leave free. However, I'm sure many people would find it more confusing.

How about  "<0 = leave that many cores free"? (cores is more correct than CPUs, by the way).
